Interval pipeline¶

Author:Andreas Heger
Release:$Id: pipeline_chipseq.py 2900 2010-04-13 14:38:00Z andreas $
Date:April 02, 2014
Tags:Python

The interval pipeline takes a several set of bed formatted genomic intervals and annotates them. The intervals are expected to be non-overlapping, which the pipeline checks.

It performs the following analyses:
  • Peak location
    • requires a bam-file to be associated with each bed-file.

  • Motif discovery using MEME

  • Motif detection using MAST
    • requires a set of known motifs

  • Overlap with genomic context.

  • Aggregate transcript/gene profiles

Usage¶

See Setting up a pipeline and Running a pipeline on general information how to use CGAT pipelines.

Configuration¶

The pipeline requires a configured pipeline.ini file. The pipeline looks for a configuration file in several places:

  1. The default configuration in the code directory.
  2. A shared configuration file ../pipeline.ini.
  3. A local configuration pipeline.ini.

The order is as above. Thus, a local configuration setting will override a shared configuration setting and a default configuration setting.

Configuration files follow the ini format (see the python ConfigParser <http://docs.python.org/library/configparser.html> documentation). The configuration file is organized by section and the variables are documented within the file. In order to get a local configuration file in the current directory, type:

python <codedir>/pipeline_chipseq.py config

The following sections and parameters probably should be changed from the default values:

Todo

describe important parameters

The sphinxreport report requires a conf.py and sphinxreport.ini file (see Building pipeline reports). To start with, use the files supplied with the Example data.

Input¶

Intervals¶

Input are bed-formatted files of intervals. Intervals should be at least bed4 formatted, i.e., each interval should be labelled (uniquely).

Optional inputs¶

Optinally, peaks can be supplied as bed formatted files. These peak files will then be processed in the same way as peaks called within the pipeline. Use the option tracks_extra to declare any additional tracks.

Additional peak files can be associated with one of the bam files created by the pipeline. This permits counting the number of tags inside peaks, finding the peak summit, etc. In order to associated a peak file with a bam formatted file, define a section in the pipeline.ini file. For example:

[mycalls.bed]
track=tissue-sample-agg

will process the file mycalls.bed exactly the same way as the track tissue-sample-agg. Replicates can be specified explicitely:

[mycalls.bed]
replicates=tissue1-sample1-R1,tissue1-sample1-R2

will associate the file mycalls.bed with the replicates tissue1-sample1-R1 and tissue1-sample1-R2. Note that globs don’t work for this yet, all replicates have to be specified explicitely.

Reference motifs¶

Reference motifs are described by fasta-formatted multiple alignments, see for example Jaspar download. The motifs are build by running MEME on the file.

Reference motifs should end in the suffix ”.motif.fasta”, for example, rxrvdr.motif.fasta.

Requirements¶

The pipeline requires the information from the following pipelines:

Annotation pipeline
set the configuration variable annotations_database and annotations_dir.

On top of the default CGAT setup, the pipeline requires the following software to be in the path:

Program Version Purpose
     

Pipline Output¶

The results of the computation are all stored in an sqlite relational database csvdb.

Example¶

Example data is available at http://www.cgat.org/~andreas/sample_data/pipeline_chipseq.tgz. To run the example, simply unpack and untar:

wget http://www.cgat.org/~andreas/sample_data/pipeline_chipseq.tgz
tar -xvzf pipeline_chipseq.tgz
cd pipeline_chipseq
python <srcdir>/pipeline_chipseq.py make full

Note

For the pipeline to run, install the Annotation pipeline as well.

Change Log¶

26.2.2014 Andreas Heger
added tag counting in intervals.
11.3.2014 Andreas Heger

preprocess all intervals to make sure they are properly formatted: 1. merge overlapping intervals 2. sort intervals by coordinate

As a consequence of this change, intervals and subsequent files will end up in the intervals.dir directory. Thus, existing pipelines will re-run.

Code¶

pipeline_intervals.getAssociatedBAMFiles(track)¶

return a list of BAM files associated with a track.

By default, this method searches for track.bam file in the data directory and returns an offset of 0.

Associations can be defined in the .ini file in the section [bams]. For example, the following snippet associates track track1 with the bamfiles track1.bam and track2.bam:

[bams]
track1=track1.bam,track2.bam

Glob expressions are permitted.

Offsets are used to shift tags in ChIP experiments. Offsets need to be defined in the [offsets] sections. If no offsets are defined, the method returns a list of 0 offsets.

Offsets need to be defined in the same order as the bam files:

[offsets]
track1=120,200

returns a list of BAM files and offsets.

Default tracks and offsets can be specified using a placeholder %. The following will associate all tracks with the same bam file:

[bams]
%=all.bam
pipeline_intervals.connect()¶

connect to database.

This method also attaches to helper databases.

pipeline_intervals.prepareIntervals(infile, outfile)¶

optionally preprocess intervals.

  1. Sort intervals by position.
  2. Merge overlapping intervals.
  3. Rename intervals: sequential number.
pipeline_intervals.indexIntervals(infile, outfile)¶

index intervals.

pipeline_intervals.loadIntervals(infile, outfile)¶

load intervals from bed formatted files into the database.

If a bam file is associated with a bed file, re-evaluate the intervals by counting reads within the interval. In contrast to the initial pipeline, the genome is not binned.

nprobes: number of reads in interval peakcenter: position with maximum number of reads in interval avgval: average coverage within interval
pipeline_intervals.exportPeakLocations(infile, outfile)¶

export peak locations

pipeline_intervals.buildContextStats(infiles, outfile)¶

build mapping context stats.

Examines the genomic context to where reads align.

A read is assigned to the genomic context that it overlaps by at least 50%. Thus some reads mapping several contexts might be dropped.

pipeline_intervals.loadContextStats(infiles, outfile)¶

load context mapping statistics.

pipeline_intervals.annotateIntervalsFull(infile, outfile)¶

classify chipseq intervals according to their location with respect to the gene set.

pipeline_intervals.annotateIntervalsPeak(infile, outfile)¶

classify chipseq intervals according to their location with respect to the gene set.

pipeline_intervals.annotateBindingFull(infile, outfile)¶

classify chipseq intervals according to their location with respect to the gene set.

Binding is counted for the full intervals.

pipeline_intervals.annotateBindingPeak(infile, outfile)¶

classify chipseq intervals according to their location with respect to the gene set.

Binding is counted for peaks.

pipeline_intervals.annotateTSS(infile, outfile)¶

compute distance to TSS

pipeline_intervals.annotateTSSPeaks(infile, outfile)¶

compute distance to TSS

pipeline_intervals.annotateRepeats(infile, outfile)¶

count the overlap between intervals and repeats.

pipeline_intervals.annotateNucleotides(infile, outfile)¶

get the nucleotide composition of the intervals

pipeline_intervals.loadAnnotations(infile, outfile)¶

load interval annotations: genome architecture

pipeline_intervals.loadBinding(infile, outfile)¶

load interval binding: genome architecture

pipeline_intervals.loadTSS(infile, outfile)¶

load interval annotations: distance to transcription start sites

pipeline_intervals.loadRepeats(infile, outfile)¶

load interval annotations: repeats

pipeline_intervals.loadNucleotides(infile, outfile)¶

load interval annotations: nucleotide composition

pipeline_intervals.buildIntervalProfileOfTranscripts(infiles, outfile)¶

build a table with the overlap profile of transcripts.

pipeline_intervals.prepareGTFsByOverlapWithIntervals(infile, outfiles)¶

Prepare GTF file of overlapping and non-overlapping genes for profile plots

pipeline_intervals.annotateTSSNucleotides(infile, outfile)¶

get the nucleotide composition of the intervals

pipeline_intervals.loadTSSNucleotides(infile, outfile)¶

load interval annotations: nucleotide composition

pipeline_intervals.buildGenesByIntervalsProfiles(infile, outfile)¶

Make gene profile plots.

pipeline_intervals.loadByIntervalProfiles(infile, outfile)¶

load interval annotations: nucleotide composition

pipeline_intervals.buildPeakShapeTable(infile, outfile)¶

build a table with peak shape parameters.

pipeline_intervals.loadPeakShapeTable(infile, outfile)¶

load peak shape information.

pipeline_intervals.buildOverlap(infiles, outfile)¶

compute overlap between intervals.

pipeline_intervals.loadOverlap(infile, outfile)¶

load overlap results.

pipeline_intervals.exportMotifSequences(infile, outfile)¶

export sequences for motif discovery.

This method requires the _interval tables.

For motif discovery, only the sequences with the highest S/N ratio are supplied.

  1. The top motifs_proportion intervals sorted by peakval

  2. Only a region +/- motifs_halfwidth around the peak

  3. At least motifs_min_sequences. If there are not enough sequences

    to start with, all will be used.

  4. At most motifs_max_size sequences will be output.

pipeline_intervals.exportMotifIntervalSequences(infile, outfile)¶

export sequences for motif detection.

This method requires the _interval tables.

pipeline_intervals.exportMotifControlSequences(infile, outfile)¶

for each interval, export the left and right sequence segment of the same size.

pipeline_intervals.runMeme(infile, outfile)¶

run MEME to find motifs.

In order to increase the signal/noise ratio, MEME is not run on all intervals but only the top 10% of intervals (peakval) are used. Also, only the segment of 200 bp around the peak is used and not the complete interval.

  • Softmasked sequence is converted to hardmasked sequence to avoid the detection of spurious motifs.
  • Sequence is run through dustmasker
pipeline_intervals.loadMemeSummary(infiles, outfile)¶

load information about motifs into database.

pipeline_intervals.loadMotifSequenceComposition(infile, outfile)¶

compute sequence composition of sequences used for ab-initio search.

pipeline_intervals.loadMotifInformation(infiles, outfile)¶

load information about motifs into database.

pipeline_intervals.runTomTom(infile, outfile)¶

compare ab-initio motifs against tomtom.

pipeline_intervals.loadTomTom(infile, outfile)¶

load tomtom results

pipeline_intervals.runMast(infiles, outfile)¶

run mast on all intervals and motifs.

Collect all results for an E-value up to 10000 so that all sequences are output and MAST curves can be computed.

10000 is a heuristic.

pipeline_intervals.loadMast(infile, outfile)¶

parse mast file and load into database.

Parse several motif runs and add them to the same table.

Add columns for the control data as well.

pipeline_intervals.exportMotifLocations(infiles, outfile)¶

export motif locations. There will be a bed-file per motif.

Overlapping motif matches in different tracks will be merged.

pipeline_intervals.runGATOnGenomicContext(infiles, outfile)¶

run gat agains genomic context.

The workspace is composed of all mapable regions. Enrichment is controlled by isochores.

To be rigorous, FDR should be re-computed after merging all analyses.

pipeline_intervals.runGATOnGenomicAnnotations(infiles, outfile)¶

run gat agains genomic context.

The workspace is composed of all mapable regions. Enrichment is controlled by isochores.

To be rigorous, FDR should be re-computed after merging all analyses.

pipeline_intervals.runGATOnGeneStructure(infiles, outfile)¶

run gat on gene structures

The purpose of this gat run is to test for differential location of intervals in parts of certain gene structures.

The workspace is composed of all mapable regions. The workspace is restricted to annotations in order to reduce the effect of intergenic depletion. Furthermore, the workspace is restricted to those parts that contain segments and annotations in order to avoid a gene bias (only genes of a certain structure contain segments).

Enrichment is controlled by isochores.

To be rigorous, FDR should be re-computed after merging all analyses.

pipeline_intervals.runGATOnGeneAnnotations(infiles, outfile)¶

run gat against genes and their annotations.

The workspace is composed of all mapable regions within gene territories. Enrichment is controlled by isochores.

To be rigorous, FDR should be re-computed after merging all analyses.

pipeline_intervals.runGATOnSets(infiles, outfile, workspacefile, isochorefile)¶

run gat on intervals against each other.

pipeline_intervals.loadGat(infile, outfile)¶

load individual gat results.

pipeline_intervals.summarizeGAT(infiles, outfile)¶

summarize GAT results.

outputs a log2fold and pvalue table for results.

The results are filtered. Remove all rows that
  • have no significant results (fdr)
  • expected overlap less than 1kb.
pipeline_intervals.prepareTags(infile, outfile)¶

prepare tag files from bam files for counting

pipeline_intervals.computeReadCountsInIntervals(infiles, outfile)¶

compute a table of read counts of each BAM-file with respect to all interval sets.

pipeline_intervals.aggregateReadCounts(infiles, outfile)¶

aggregate tag counts into single files per interval set.

pipeline_intervals.summarizeReadCounts(infile, outfile)¶

perform summarization of read counts

pipeline_intervals.full()¶

run the full pipeline.

pipeline_intervals.build_report()¶

build report from scratch.

pipeline_intervals.update_report()¶

update report.

pipeline_intervals.publish()¶

publish files.
